General UNIX | Distributions

Since there are so many variations on UNIX systems, we're focusing on modern day UNIX-like operating systems, such as the family of Linux distributions.


A software distribution is a collection of applications and other software components that are available to the user once they install it. An example of this would be distributions of operating systems derived from UNIX, such as the Berkeley Software Distribution (BSD) and Linux, which in turn have their own distributions.


Check out our Resources area after this lesson to find out more about the various distributions available!


Fun Fact: BSD's distributions would later form the basis of the operating systems of macOS and iOS.
